Plus/Minus Grades
Approved By CUS
BY PETER CINQUEGRANI
The controversial issue of
plus/minus grading at Hopkins
will go before the Academic
Council should the Committee
on Undergraduate Studies vote
in favor of the more detailed
grading system. The Committee
consists of five faculty members
and four students.
The proposal to begin
plus/minus grading was first
forwarded last year and passed
unanimously by the CUS. Subsequently, students were given
the opportunity to express their
feelings on plus/minus grading in
a referendum. Students voted
against the plan 60-40. The CUS
then moved to reconsider the
original motion on plus/minus
grading.
The plan currently under
consideration was set forth by
James Walker of the Physics
department. In discussion before
the CUS, Walker said he supported the plan because he
felt that it would reduce competition. lie said that lie has had
numerous requests to regrade
since one point can make the
difference between a grade that
is almost an A or nearly a C with
no means of differentiating
more closely. He stated that
there was legitimate uncertainty
among faculty members in assigning borderline grades when
such large gradations are at
stake.
Walker also noted that the
lack of plus/minus grading has
been detrimental to Hopkins
students applying to graduate or
professional schools. A number
of the better schools have always
had plus/minus grading, and
others have now moved back to
that system. He expressed the
feeling that if grades are to be

given at all they should be as
meaningful as possible.
Dean Hooker indicated that
he agrees with Walker's reasoning, but felt that the students
were approaching the proposal
as an emotional issue, preferring
the "familiar evil" of whole
grades to the uncertainty of
plus/minus grading.
In further discussion, Professor Hall of the Psychology
department pointed out that the
faculty has had no hidden
interest in the plus/minus system, that they were motivated
by the feeling that it is in the
best interests of the students.
She noted that the system was
not less troublesome for the
faculty, but they simply feel it is
not fair.
A motion by Robert Elkin
and George Connolly to rescind
last year's committee motion in
favor of the plus/minus system
failed, seven to two.
Mathematical Sciences Professor Karr moved that the
following system of grading be
adopted for all students in
September of 1980, or as soon as
it is feasable: A=4.0, A-=3.7,
B+=3.3, B=3.0, 13-=2.7, C+=2.3,
C=2.0, C-=1.7, D=1.0, F=0. D+,
D- and A+ are not being considered so that the 4.0 scale
can be retained. The motion was
passed, seven in favor, none
opposed and two abstaining.
The motion will now go to
the Academic Council, made up
of 12 faculty members with all
the full deans as ex-officio
members and Steven Muller
chairman.The
ex-officio
as
Council has the final authority
on the issue.

already expressed its opposition
to the grading change. They

BY SUNITA HANJURA
The subject of plus/minus
grading dominated the Student
Council meeting Wednesday
night. Sid Goodfriend, S.C.
secretary, motioned that the
Council should issue a statement
declaring their opposition to
plus/minus grading, since he
feels that the Academic Council
is not concerned enough about
the issue. Goodfriend presented
an "endorsement in principle"
that will be issued, subject to
revisions.
The Council discussed the
pros and cons of the new grading
system, and two members who
had changed their opinions to
support it presented their arguments. The majority, however,
still opposes plus/minus grading.
The final draft of Goodfriend's
statement outlining the Council's position on the new grading
procedure was scheduled to be
presented to Dean Hooker by
the end of this week.
Jeff Aronson, co-chairperson of the Spring Fair, stated
that in the light of the current
political situation, and because
of problems getting the games
arranged, the theme of the
Spring Fair will be changed from
that of the Olympic Games to a

Musical Celebration. The Council also revealed that it has
completed the Judicial Code
(formerly the Conduct Code)
and plans to issue it for student
referendum by April 1st.
On the issue of mandatory
retirement at age 65, the Council
discussed the reinstatement of
Dr. Stanton, Dr. Stein and
perhaps a member of the Sciences faculty. Dr. Stanton will
teach all her regular classes after
a 70-signature petition and several letters were written in
protest of her forced retirement.
Dr. Stein of the English department will also be able to teach
because of several reasons, including student intervention.
The Council considered
plans to construct a new building on the University's Wyman
Park property as an issue that
will have ramifications in

We suppose it would be easy for a
collegiate newspaper to do the expected
thing and angrily rail against President
Carter's proposed reinstitution of registration for military service. Since the men
(and perhaps the women) who make up the
student body of this University will be
the people directly affected by such a
move, it is tempting to take the narrow
view. Very tempting... and equally wrong.
In his State of the Union address
Wednesday night, President Carter emphasized the fact that at this point in history,
the fate of America is intimately bound up
with the fate of many faraway nations.
The Persian Gull and the Straits of Hormuz
are just as far away as Vietnam, and
the distances, both geographically and
culturally, make their vital importance to
every facet of our lives hard to envision.
Nevertheless, our dependence on their
independence is an undeniable fact -- and
ignoring facts for the sake of a short-term
illusion of safety is the surest road to
long-term peril.
One of the fundamental things which
anyone who has received a college education should know is that generalizations are

dangerous, and every situation must be
judged on its own merits. It may be a
bitter pill for many undergrads to swallow,
but the 60's are otter. (As a matter of fact
the 70's have bitten the dust as well.) The
current world situation is by no means the
same as it was fifteen years ago, and
individuals must _formulate their opinions
about military service anew. There seems
to be a feeling around campus that students
must necessarily be opposed to any resurrection of Selective Service, as if anti-military sentiment was a required course. Such
shallow, self-serving avoidance of considering the issues is an excuse we employ at our
peril.
Registration is necessary. The armed
forces of the United States are at this
moment understrengthed by approximately 800,000 !rpm, and each week the
deterence which only a strong military can
provide becomes increasingly vital. Anyone who thinks he is protecting his individual rights or guaranteeing the continuence
of his accustomed way of life by opposing
registration is suffering from a serious case
of moral near-sightedness.

The young men of this
country and perhaps the young
women, too, face the prospect
of involuntary military service to
their country.
The move to reinstitute
registration for the selective
service system comes as one of a
series of moves designed to

realization that this would probably be the only concert
this winter that would mean anything. It was the hope
that the boys could bounce back from adversity and pull

It was the return of the Who.
Yeah, maybe you should have been home studying for that final exam, but since when does school take
precedence over the Who? This was to be the Who's first
visit since 1976, and there were questions to be answered:
After Cincinnati, would the group merely be
going through the motions?
Would Kenny Jones prove to be a suitable
replacement for Keith Moon?
How effectively would a horn section and a
keyboardist mesh with the group?
Would the Who be looking back to the sixties, or
ahead to the eighties?
Clearly, many in the audience faced towards the
sixties. "Man, I could really get into seeing Townshend
smash his guitar," one glassy-eyed youth observed in the
men's room before the show. One long toke off a PCP

Townshend hasn't obliterated a guitar in years. Still,
after every show, it's inevitable that some people will go

how to remove the damn thing is anybody's guess.

been tarnished.

survivors.

considerable promise for the eighties.

forwarded last year and passed
unanimously by the CUS. Subsequently, students were given
the opportunity to express their
feelings on plus/minus grading in
a referendum. Students voted
against the plan 60-40. The CUS
then moved to reconsider the
original motion on plus/minus
grading.

James Walker of the Physics

the CUS, Walker said he supported the plan because he
felt that it would reduce competition. lie said that lie has had
numerous requests to regrade
since one point can make the
difference between a grade that
is almost an A or nearly a C with
no means of differentiating
more closely. He stated that
there was legitimate uncertainty
among faculty members in assigning borderline grades when
such large gradations are at
stake.
Walker also noted that the
lack of plus/minus grading has
been detrimental to Hopkins
students applying to graduate or
professional schools. A number
of the better schools have always
had plus/minus grading, and
others have now moved back to
that system. He expressed the
feeling that if grades are to be

meaningful as possible.

the "familiar evil" of whole
grades to the uncertainty of
plus/minus grading.

faculty has had no hidden
interest in the plus/minus system, that they were motivated
by the feeling that it is in the
best interests of the students.

not less troublesome for the
faculty, but they simply feel it is
not fair.

last year's committee motion in

Kill The Draft
BY PETER CINQUEGRANI

The young men of this
country and perhaps the young
women, too, face the prospect
of involuntary military service to
their country.
The move to reinstitute
registration for the selective
service system comes as one of a
series of moves designed to
demonstrate America's will to
stand up to the Soviet Union.
Citizens' lives and happiness
should not be pieces in their
own government's strategic chess
game.
To believe that it is possible
to have registration without the
draft following is to believe that
you can be almost pregnant. Yet
the draft was one of the most
disruptive forces in American
society. Any system which tries
to pick who will fight will have
built-in inequalities. College deferments would result in a
working-class Army defending
the middle class at home. Yet, it
is important to continue producing educated minds and
professionals.
Any system which forces

men to do what they do not
want to do is one of involuntary
servitude--slavery. To force
someone to fight when they
do not want to is wrong. If
America is worth defending, it
must be worth defending because you wish to, not because
the government forces you to.
Patriots cannot be drafted;
they would already have joined.
In peace time draftees are never
happy or good soldiers. They do
not have the esprit de corps
necessary to form part of an
effective fighting force.
There is a basic contradiction in the draft in America. In
peacetime, when soldiers do no
fighting, the public does not
support the draft and draftees
are unwilling to serve. However,
during times of crisis, when
soldiers are needed, the population is willing to support the
draft and even upstages it by
enlisting. When the draft is most
needed in crises, it is not necessary to bring the men in, while
in peacetime when soldiers are
not fighting, the draft is not
effective.
